column1: Temara (Arabic: تمارة‎; Berber languages: ⵜⵎⴰⵔⴰ) is a coastal city in Morocco.
It is located in the region of Rabat-Salé-Kénitra
column2: directly south of Rabat on the Atlantic coast
column3: in the suburban area of the capital. The city has 313
column4: 510 inhabitants as of 2014 and is the capital of Skhirate-Témara Prefecture. It is twinned with Saint Germain en Laye
column5: France. The city has beaches and a small pleasure port.

column1: Temara was founded in the twelfth century (1130–1163) by Sultan Othman El Arfaoui
column2: who built a mosque there. Five centuries later
column3: Mulai Ismail built the current wall and made from Temara a ribat (casern) around Said mosque. Later
column4: Mulay Abd ar-Rahman (1822–1859) and Mulay Abdul Aziz (1894–1908)
column5: completed (Kasbah of the Udayas) as religious and military camps.

column1: Temara has a hot-summer Mediterranean climate (Köppen climate classification Csa). In winter there is more rainfall than in summer. The average annual temperature in Temara is 17.8 °C (64.0 °F). About 505 mm (19.88 in) of precipitation falls annually.
Temara is close to Morocco's two main cities
Two main zones share the essence of the industrial units in the city of Temara. The first is in the direction of Casablanca
column3: with a total area of 120 hectares
column4: extensible to 300 Ha work 55 industrial units in this zone
column5: contains the more clean industry sectors (textiles
column8: food). The second industrial zone is at the other end of town
column9: in the direction of Rabat. It is the industrial zone Attasnia

column1: The population was at first constituted by Zaer tribes and different tribes of Oudayas (Military groups from different regions of Morocco were established by the Sultan
column2: as exchange of their Military service to the Sultan they had the right to cultivate the land). Now the population was diversified by all ethnicities in Morocco: Arabs and various Amazigh groups (Riffians
